title: WFU Agentic AI Workgroup
text:
Project instructions



This is a faculty/staff workgroup at Wake Forest University focused on agentic AI tools in the CLI. It is not a credit-bearing course — there are no grades, no formal assessment, and membership is rolling (participants join and leave at any time).

Audience: WFU faculty and staff with little or no CLI experience
Format: Weekly in-person meetings + async web content
Facilitator: Will Fleeson (Department of Psychology)
Deliverable: A Quarto website deployed to GitHub Pages




The workgroup moves participants from zero CLI knowledge toward independent use of agentic AI tools:

Navigate the file system and run commands in a terminal
Use Git and GitHub for version control and collaboration
Configure shell environments and dotfiles
Interact with Claude Code for agentic coding workflows
Access and configure APIs for AI services
Set up and use MCP servers for tool integration
Author reproducible documents with Markdown and Quarto




When writing tutorials, session notes, or resource pages:

Assume zero CLI knowledge. Define terms on first use. Explain what commands do before showing them.
Progressive difficulty. Early content covers basic navigation and file operations. Later content introduces Git, Claude Code, APIs, and MCPs.
Worked examples over abstractions. Show a concrete task, walk through the steps, then generalize. Avoid leading with theory.
Copy-paste friendly. Code blocks should be runnable as-is. Include expected output where helpful.
Platform awareness. Most participants use macOS, but some use Windows. Tutorials should default to macOS examples and note Windows differences (e.g., PowerShell vs bash, path separators, installer commands) in callouts or inline when behavior diverges.
No jargon without context. If a term is unavoidable, define it inline or link to the glossary.





Shell: bash (default macOS shell via Terminal.app or iTerm2)
Version control: Git + GitHub
AI tools: Claude Code (CLI), Anthropic API, MCP servers
Authoring: Markdown, Quarto (.qmd files)
Deployment: GitHub Pages via quarto publish gh-pages
Environment: Nix flake for reproducible development setup




index.qmd          — Landing page (welcome, meeting info, getting started)
about.qmd          — Purpose, learning goals, format, facilitator
sessions/          — Session notes, one file per meeting (date-based)
  index.qmd        — Session log, reverse chronological
tutorials/         — Self-contained topic tutorials
  index.qmd        — Tutorial catalog with difficulty indicators
  01-cli-basics.qmd
  02-working-with-paths.qmd
  03-shell-configuration.qmd
  04-git-fundamentals.qmd
  05-github-collaboration.qmd
  06-claude-code-intro.qmd
  07-apis-and-mcps.qmd
resources/         — Reference material
  index.qmd        — Resource hub
  cheatsheets.qmd
  tools.qmd
  troubleshooting.qmd
  glossary.qmd


Create sessions/YYYY-MM-DD.qmd with front matter:
---
title: "Session title"
date: "YYYY-MM-DD"
description: "Brief summary of what was covered."
---
The listing on sessions/index.qmd picks up new session files automatically.



Create tutorials/topic-name.qmd with front matter that includes categories (one of "Getting started", "Version control", or "AI tools"):
---
title: "Tutorial title"
description: "Brief description of the tutorial."
date: "YYYY-MM-DD"
categories: ["Getting started"]
---
The listing on tutorials/index.qmd picks up new tutorial files automatically.





Theme: flatly (Bootstrap-based, clean and readable)
Code blocks: Use code-copy: true and code-tools: true for interactive code
External links: Open in new window (link-external-newwindow: true)
Front matter: Every .qmd file needs title at minimum; tutorials should also have description and date
Callouts: Use Quarto callouts (.callout-note, .callout-tip, .callout-warning) for asides and important information
Images: Store in an images/ subdirectory relative to the page that uses them




Follow the conventions in the global ~/.claude/CLAUDE.md:

R: tidyverse, native pipe (|>), 2-space indent
Python: data science stack, ruff, 4-space indent
Bash: POSIX-compliant, 2-space indent
Line limit: 80 characters (except Markdown)
Naming: snake_case (functions/variables)
Lists: Use - not * or +
Conventional commits: type(scope): message




The specs/ directory contains planning, progress, and implementation documents for the workgroup. These files are excluded from the rendered site (via .gitignore and not being listed in _quarto.yml). They are internal project management documents.

title: APIs and MCPs
text:
APIs let you access AI models programmatically. MCP (Model Context Protocol) servers extend what AI assistants can do by connecting them to external tools and data sources. This tutorial covers API key management, basic API usage, and setting up MCP servers.
Prerequisites: Claude Code introduction Estimated time: 35 minutes






Note



Content in progress. Check back soon or attend a workgroup session for a guided walkthrough.

title: APIs and MCPs
text:

Note

title: GitHub collaboration
text:
GitHub hosts Git repositories online and provides tools for collaboration. This tutorial covers working with remote repositories, pushing and pulling changes, creating pull requests, and reviewing code.
Prerequisites: Git fundamentals Estimated time: 30 minutes






Note



Content in progress. Check back soon or attend a workgroup session for a guided walkthrough.

title: GitHub collaboration
text:
GitHub hosts Git repositories online and provides tools for collaboration. This tutorial covers working with remote repositories, pushing and pulling changes, creating pull requests, and reviewing code.

title: Shell configuration
text:
Your shell reads configuration files (dotfiles) every time it starts. This tutorial explains how to customize your terminal by editing these files, setting environment variables, and creating aliases for common commands.
Prerequisites: Working with paths Estimated time: 25 minutes






Note



Content in progress. Check back soon or attend a workgroup session for a guided walkthrough.

title: Tutorials
text:
Work through these tutorials in order, or jump to whichever topic you need.


    
      
      
    








CLI basics



Getting started



Open a terminal, run your first commands, and work with files and directories.










Working with paths



Getting started



Understand absolute and relative paths, the home directory, and how to navigate the file system.










Shell configuration



Getting started



Customize your terminal with dotfiles, environment variables, and aliases.










Git fundamentals



Version control



Track changes to your files with Git: init, add, commit, log, and diff.










GitHub collaboration



Version control



Push code to GitHub, collaborate with pull requests, and review changes.










Claude Code introduction



AI tools



Install Claude Code, configure it for your projects, and start an agentic coding workflow.










APIs and MCPs



AI tools



Configure API keys for AI services and set up Model Context Protocol servers.





No matching items

title: WFU Agentic AI Workgroup
text: This workgroup brings together Wake Forest University faculty and staff who want to learn how to use agentic AI tools from the command line. We start from scratch — no prior terminal experience required — and work our way toward using tools like Claude Code, APIs, and MCP servers in everyday academic workflows.

title: WFU Agentic AI Workgroup
text: This workgroup brings together Wake Forest University faculty and staff who want to learn how to use agentic AI tools from the command line. We start from scratch — no prior terminal experience required — and work our way toward using tools like Claude Code, APIs, and MCP servers in everyday academic workflows.

title: WFU Agentic AI Workgroup
text:
Meeting info

When: Weekly (see sessions for schedule)
Where: In person at WFU (location TBA)/ or via Zoom (link in calendar invite)
Who: Any WFU faculty or staff member — join anytime

title: WFU Agentic AI Workgroup
text:
Getting started
New to the workgroup? Start here:

CLI basics — Open a terminal and run your first commands
Working with paths — Navigate the file system with confidence
Shell configuration — Customize your terminal environment

Then move on to version control and AI tools when you’re ready.

title: About
text: The WFU Agentic AI Workgroup is a space for faculty and staff to build hands-on skills with command-line AI tools. The goal is practical fluency: by participating, you’ll be able to use the terminal, manage files with Git, and work with AI assistants like Claude Code in your own projects.

title: About
text: The WFU Agentic AI Workgroup is a space for faculty and staff to build hands-on skills with command-line AI tools. The goal is practical fluency: by participating, you’ll be able to use the terminal, manage files with Git, and work with AI assistants like Claude Code in your own projects.

title: About
text:
Learning goals
By the end of the tutorial sequence, participants will be able to:

Navigate the file system and run commands in a terminal
Use Git and GitHub for version control and collaboration
Configure shell environments and dotfiles
Work with Claude Code (and/or other CLI tools) for agentic coding workflows
Access and configure APIs for AI services
Set up and use MCP servers for tool integration
Author reproducible documents with Markdown and Quarto

title: About
text:
Format

Weekly meetings — Brief demos followed by hands-on practice. Meetings are standalone; missing one doesn’t block your progress.
Async content — All topics are covered in written tutorials on this site. You can learn entirely at your own pace.
Rolling membership — Join anytime. New participants start with the CLI basics tutorial and work forward.
Professional development — Self-assessment prompts in tutorials help you gauge your own progress.

title: About
text:
What you’ll need

A terminal — macOS: Terminal.app (built-in) or iTerm2. Windows: Windows Terminal with PowerShell or Git Bash.
A GitHub account — Sign up free at github.com. Faculty can also apply for GitHub Education benefits, which include Copilot access and private repository extras.
A text editor — VS Code recommended (cross-platform), but any editor works.
Claude Code — Installed during an early session. See the Claude Code docs for details.

title: About
text:
Facilitator
Will Fleeson – Department of Psychology, Wake Forest University
Questions? Open an issue on GitHub or reach out directly.

title: Git fundamentals
text:
Git is a version control system that tracks changes to your files over time. This tutorial covers the core Git workflow: initializing a repository, staging changes, committing snapshots, and reviewing history.
Prerequisites: Shell configuration Estimated time: 30 minutes






Note



Content in progress. Check back soon or attend a workgroup session for a guided walkthrough.

title: Git fundamentals
text:
Git is a version control system that tracks changes to your files over time. This tutorial covers the core Git workflow: initializing a repository, staging changes, committing snapshots, and reviewing history.
Prerequisites: Shell configuration Estimated time: 30 minutes






Note



Content in progress. Check back soon or attend a workgroup session for a guided walkthrough.

title: CLI basics
text:
This tutorial introduces the command-line interface (CLI). You’ll learn how to open a terminal on macOS, run basic commands, and create, move, and delete files and directories.
Prerequisites: None Estimated time: 30 minutes






Note



Content in progress. Check back soon or attend a workgroup session for a guided walkthrough.

title: CLI basics

title: Working with paths
text:
Paths tell the terminal where to find files. This tutorial covers the difference between absolute and relative paths, what the home directory is, and how to move around the file system confidently.
Prerequisites: CLI basics Estimated time: 20 minutes






Note



Content in progress. Check back soon or attend a workgroup session for a guided walkthrough.

title: Claude Code introduction
text:
Claude Code is an agentic AI assistant that runs in your terminal. This tutorial walks through installation, configuration, and basic usage — including how to give Claude Code context about your project and work with it effectively.
Prerequisites: GitHub collaboration Estimated time: 30 minutes






Note



Content in progress. Check back soon or attend a workgroup session for a guided walkthrough.
